exam_title: CAAP PPL Airman Knowledge - Aircraft General Knowledge (AGK)

questions.question_text: According to the provided text, what type of fuel is commonly used in Cessna 152-172 aircraft?
questions.correct_answer: Avgas 100LL (Blue) or 100 (Green)

questions.question_text: Which type of fuel system relies solely on gravity to deliver fuel to the engine?
questions.correct_answer: Gravity Feed System

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of the primer in a fuel system?
options: To filter the fuel before it enters the engine
To measure the fuel quantity in the tanks
To inject a small amount of fuel directly into the cylinders for easier starting
To switch between different fuel tanks
questions.correct_answer: To inject a small amount of fuel directly into the cylinders for easier starting

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the fuel sump drain ports?
options: To add fuel to the tanks
To allow testing of fuel for contaminants like water or sediment
questions.correct_answer: To allow testing of fuel for contaminants like water or sediment

questions.question_text: Why is there always some unusable fuel in aircraft fuel tanks?
options: It serves as a reserve for emergencies
It is below the level of the fuel line pickup point
It is required for weight and balance
It is used to cool the fuel pumps
questions.correct_answer: It is below the level of the fuel line pickup point

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT listed as a primary function of the engine oil system?
options: Cooling the engine by reducing friction
Providing fuel pressure to the carburetor
questions.correct_answer: Providing fuel pressure to the carburetor

questions.question_text: What type of oil system is typically used in the aircraft discussed to reduce weight?
questions.correct_answer: Wet Sump System

questions.question_text: What type of oil is recommended for the first 50 hours of engine operation (break-in period)?
questions.correct_answer: Aviation Straight Grade Oil

questions.question_text: A rapid drop in oil pressure to zero most likely indicates:
options: A blockage in the oil system
A blown oil line or oil pump failure
The oil quantity is slightly low
questions.correct_answer: A blown oil line or oil pump failure

questions.question_text: What does an abnormally high oil temperature reading typically indicate?
options: The oil pump is not functional
There is a blockage in the oil system
The oil quantity is too high
questions.correct_answer: The engine is overheating

questions.question_text: Which component is used to manually check the engine oil quantity?
questions.correct_answer: Dipstick

questions.question_text: What is a major consequence of operating an engine at higher than its designed temperature?
options: Loss of power and potential engine damage
questions.correct_answer: Loss of power and potential engine damage

questions.question_text: Which components on the engine cylinders help dissipate heat into the surrounding air?
questions.correct_answer: Cooling Fins

questions.question_text: What is the function of cowl flaps?
options: To increase aerodynamic drag during landing
To control the amount of cooling air flowing over the engine
To direct exhaust gases away from the cabin
questions.correct_answer: To control the amount of cooling air flowing over the engine

questions.question_text: How is cabin heating typically provided in many light aircraft?
options: Using an electric heater powered by the battery
Using residual heat from the avionics
Using fresh air heated by the exhaust system muffler
questions.correct_answer: Using fresh air heated by the exhaust system muffler

questions.question_text: What does the Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) gauge measure?
options: The temperature of the engine oil
The temperature of the gases at the exhaust manifold
The temperature of the cylinder heads
questions.correct_answer: The temperature of the gases at the exhaust manifold

questions.question_text: What are the typical DC voltages found in aircraft electrical systems mentioned in the text?
questions.correct_answer: 14 or 28 volts

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of the aircraft battery when the engine is not running?
options: To provide primary power for all systems
To provide power for starting the engine and emergency power
To regulate the voltage output of the alternator
questions.correct_answer: To provide power for starting the engine and emergency power

questions.question_text: Which component supplies electrical power to the system and recharges the battery once the engine is running?
questions.correct_answer: Alternator or Generator

questions.question_text: What is a key advantage of an alternator over a generator, according to the text?
options: Alternators are lighter and require less maintenance
Alternators produce more constant electrical output across a wider range of engine speeds
Generators are more reliable at low RPM
questions.correct_answer: Alternators produce more constant electrical output across a wider range of engine speeds

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of circuit breakers or fuses in an aircraft electrical system?
options: To protect circuits and equipment from electrical overload
questions.correct_answer: To protect circuits and equipment from electrical overload

questions.question_text: What does the illumination of the beacon light typically indicate?
options: The aircraft is ready for takeoff
The landing gear is down and locked
The engine is about to start or is running
questions.correct_answer: The engine is about to start or is running

questions.question_text: What are the standard colors and positions for aircraft navigation lights?
options: Left Wing: Green, Right Wing: Red, Tail: White
Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Green, Tail: White
Left Wing: White, Right Wing: White, Tail: Red
Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Red, Tail: Green
questions.correct_answer: Left Wing: Red, Right Wing: Green, Tail: White

questions.question_text: What is the function of a Bus Bar in an aircraft electrical system?
options: To provide a common connection point for distributing voltage
questions.correct_answer: To provide a common connection point for distributing voltage

questions.question_text: What does an Ammeter typically measure in an aircraft electrical system?
options: The voltage output of the alternator
The total electrical load on the system
The electrical current flowing into or out of the battery
The resistance in the electrical circuits
questions.correct_answer: The electrical current flowing into or out of the battery

questions.question_text: What does a Loadmeter typically indicate?
options: The amount of charge remaining in the battery
The rate of current flow to the battery
The total percentage load being placed on the alternator/generator
The voltage level of the electrical system
questions.correct_answer: The total percentage load being placed on the alternator/generator

questions.question_text: What system powers some gyroscopic flight instruments in many light aircraft?
questions.correct_answer: Vacuum System

questions.question_text: The pitot tube is used to measure which type of pressure?
questions.correct_answer: Total Pressure (Dynamic + Static)

questions.question_text: Which flight instrument is connected ONLY to the pitot pressure source (directly)?
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed Indicator (ASI)

questions.question_text: What pressure does the static port measure?
questions.correct_answer: Static (Ambient Atmospheric) Pressure

questions.question_text: Which flight instrument operates using BOTH pitot and static pressure?
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed Indicator (ASI)

questions.question_text: What does the Airspeed Indicator (ASI) actually measure?
options: The difference between total pressure and static pressure
questions.correct_answer: The difference between total pressure and static pressure

questions.question_text: What is Indicated Airspeed (IAS)?
options: Airspeed corrected for altitude and temperature
The uncorrected reading obtained directly from the Airspeed Indicator
The actual speed of the aircraft over the ground
questions.correct_answer: The uncorrected reading obtained directly from the Airspeed Indicator

questions.question_text: True Airspeed (TAS) is Calibrated Airspeed (CAS) corrected for:
questions.correct_answer: Altitude and non-standard temperature

questions.question_text: What does the white arc on the Airspeed Indicator represent?
questions.correct_answer: Flap operating range

questions.question_text: What is Vso?
options: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (lower limit of white arc)
Maximum speed with flaps extended (upper limit of white arc)
questions.correct_answer: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (lower limit of white arc)

questions.question_text: What does the green arc on the Airspeed Indicator represent?
questions.correct_answer: Normal operating range

questions.question_text: What speed is indicated by the red radial line on the Airspeed Indicator (Vne)?
questions.correct_answer: Never exceed speed

questions.question_text: Which V-speed represents the best angle-of-climb speed?
questions.correct_answer: Vx

questions.question_text: Which V-speed represents the best rate-of-climb speed?
questions.correct_answer: Vy

questions.question_text: The Altimeter measures the height of an aircraft above:
questions.correct_answer: A given pressure level

questions.question_text: What type of altitude is read directly from the altimeter when set to the local altimeter setting (QNH)?
questions.correct_answer: Indicated Altitude

questions.question_text: What is Pressure Altitude?
options: Actual height above Mean Sea Level (MSL)
Altitude shown when the altimeter is set to 29.92 in Hg (ISA standard pressure)
questions.correct_answer: Altitude shown when the altimeter is set to 29.92 in Hg (ISA standard pressure)

questions.question_text: Density Altitude is Pressure Altitude corrected for:
questions.correct_answer: Non-standard temperature

questions.question_text: Which altimeter setting would a pilot use to have the altimeter read the field elevation upon landing?
questions.correct_answer: QFE

questions.question_text: The Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) operates using pressure from which source?
options: Both Pitot tube and Static port
questions.correct_answer: Static port only

questions.question_text: What is the 'Trend' indication on a VSI?
options: The stabilized rate of climb or descent after 6-9 seconds
The immediate indication of a change in vertical direction
questions.correct_answer: The immediate indication of a change in vertical direction

questions.question_text: If the pitot tube becomes blocked but the drain hole remains open, what will the Airspeed Indicator show?
options: Airspeed freezes at the value when blockage occurred
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed decreases to zero

questions.question_text: If both the pitot tube opening and its drain hole become clogged, how will the Airspeed Indicator react?
options: It will freeze at the last correct indication
It will act like an altimeter (increase in climb, decrease in descent)
It will read lower than actual airspeed
questions.correct_answer: It will act like an altimeter (increase in climb, decrease in descent)

questions.question_text: If the static port becomes blocked, which instruments will provide inaccurate readings?
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed Indicator, Altimeter, and VSI

questions.question_text: What gyroscopic principle allows a gyro to remain fixed in its plane of rotation?
questions.correct_answer: Rigidity in space

questions.question_text: Which gyroscopic instrument provides pitch and roll information?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator

questions.question_text: Due to precession, the Heading Indicator must be periodically realigned with which instrument?
questions.correct_answer: Magnetic Compass

questions.question_text: How often should the Heading Indicator typically be checked and realigned during straight-and-level flight?
questions.correct_answer: Every 15 minutes

questions.question_text: What information does the Turn Coordinator provide?
questions.correct_answer: Yaw and roll

questions.question_text: What is the standard rate of turn indicated by the Turn Coordinator?
questions.correct_answer: 3 degrees per second

questions.question_text: What is Magnetic Variation?
options: Error caused by the aircraft's magnetic fields
The tendency of the compass to dip towards the poles
The angular difference between True North and Magnetic North
The error caused by accelerating or decelerating
questions.correct_answer: The angular difference between True North and Magnetic North

questions.question_text: What causes Magnetic Deviation?
options: The difference between True North and Magnetic North
Disturbances from magnetic fields produced by metals and electrical accessories within the airplane
questions.correct_answer: Disturbances from magnetic fields produced by metals and electrical accessories within the airplane

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, when accelerating on an East or West heading, the magnetic compass tends to indicate a turn towards:
questions.correct_answer: North

questions.question_text: In the Northern Hemisphere, when initiating a turn from a Northerly heading, the magnetic compass indication will initially:
questions.correct_answer: Lag behind the actual heading (Undershoot)

questions.question_text: According to PCAR Part 1, what defines an aircraft as 'Airworthy'?
options: It has passed its last inspection
It has a valid Certificate of Registration
It conforms to its approved design and is in a condition for safe operation
It has flown less than 100 hours since the last overhaul
questions.correct_answer: It conforms to its approved design and is in a condition for safe operation

questions.question_text: What is the typical validity period for a Certificate of Airworthiness in the Philippines before renewal is required?
questions.correct_answer: 1 year

questions.question_text: Which document, signed by an authorized representative of an AMO, certifies that maintenance work has been completed satisfactorily?
questions.correct_answer: Return to Service (RTS) / Maintenance Release

questions.question_text: Who holds the primary responsibility for maintaining an aircraft in an airworthy condition?
options: The Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAP)
The owner or lessee of the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: The owner or lessee of the aircraft

questions.question_text: Which instrument is required for VFR flight at night, but not necessarily during the day, according to the provided list?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude indicator

questions.question_text: What is a Supplemental Type Certificate (STC)?
options: The original approval for an aircraft design
An approval for a major change in type design of an already approved product
A certificate required for experimental aircraft
questions.correct_answer: An approval for a major change in type design of an already approved product

questions.question_text: Which aircraft category permits limited acrobatics with bank angles between 60° and 90°?
questions.correct_answer: Utility

questions.question_text: An aircraft used for agricultural purposes like crop dusting would typically fall under which category?
questions.correct_answer: Restricted

questions.question_text: What type of fuselage construction uses a substructure riveted to the skin to maintain shape and strength, common in modern light aircraft?
questions.correct_answer: Semi-monocoque

questions.question_text: Which wing planform is described as ideal for subsonic speeds but difficult to manufacture?
questions.correct_answer: Elliptical Wing

questions.question_text: Which flight control surfaces move in opposite directions to cause the airplane to roll?
questions.correct_answer: Ailerons

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of flaps?
options: To increase lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and slower landing speeds
To trim the aircraft for level flight
questions.correct_answer: To increase lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and slower landing speeds

questions.question_text: What part of the empennage controls the airplane's yaw (movement of the nose left and right)?
questions.correct_answer: Rudder

questions.question_text: What part of the empennage controls the airplane's pitch (movement of the nose up and down)?
questions.correct_answer: Elevator or Stabilator

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of an elevator trim tab?
options: To increase the structural integrity of the elevator
To help the pilot hold the elevator in a desired position, reducing control pressure
To act as a secondary elevator in case of primary control failure
To increase the effectiveness of the elevator at high speeds
questions.correct_answer: To help the pilot hold the elevator in a desired position, reducing control pressure

questions.question_text: What type of landing gear configuration has a single nose wheel and two main wheels?
questions.correct_answer: Tricycle

questions.question_text: What type of shock absorber, using air and oil, is commonly found on nose landing gear?
questions.correct_answer: Oleo Strut

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of the propeller?
options: To translate engine power into thrust
questions.correct_answer: To translate engine power into thrust

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of a 'Climb Propeller'?
options: Less twist, designed for high cruise speeds
Variable pitch controlled by the pilot
More twist (bigger bite), optimized for climb performance
questions.correct_answer: More twist (bigger bite), optimized for climb performance

questions.question_text: What is the advantage of a Constant Speed Propeller?
options: It is simpler and lighter than fixed-pitch propellers
It allows the pilot to maintain a constant airspeed
It automatically adjusts pitch to maintain a selected RPM for better efficiency
questions.correct_answer: It automatically adjusts pitch to maintain a selected RPM for better efficiency

questions.question_text: What type of engine uses the back-and-forth movement of pistons to convert pressure into rotating motion?
questions.correct_answer: Reciprocating Engine

questions.question_text: Which cylinder arrangement is noted for having a good power-to-weight ratio and good cooling but potentially large frontal area?
questions.correct_answer: Radial

questions.question_text: Which cylinder arrangement is common in light general aviation aircraft due to good cooling, less vibration, and small frontal area?
questions.correct_answer: Opposed

questions.question_text: Which engine component connects the piston to the crankshaft?
questions.correct_answer: Connecting Rod

questions.question_text: What are the four strokes of a typical reciprocating engine cycle?
questions.correct_answer: Intake, Compression, Power, Exhaust

questions.question_text: What event occurs between the compression and power strokes?
questions.correct_answer: Ignition

questions.question_text: What is detonation in an engine cylinder?
options: Normal, smooth burning of the fuel-air mixture
Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires
Uncontrolled, explosive ignition of the fuel-air mixture
Incomplete combustion resulting in black smoke
questions.correct_answer: Uncontrolled, explosive ignition of the fuel-air mixture

questions.question_text: What is pre-ignition?
options: The spark plug firing at the correct time
Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires, often caused by a hot spot
Explosive burning of the fuel-air mixture
The process of priming the engine before start
questions.correct_answer: Ignition of the fuel-air mixture before the spark plug fires, often caused by a hot spot

questions.question_text: What does the Tachometer indicate?
options: Engine crankshaft speed in RPM (Revolutions Per Minute)
questions.correct_answer: Engine crankshaft speed in RPM (Revolutions Per Minute)

questions.question_text: Under what conditions is carburetor icing most likely, according to the text?
options: Only when visible moisture is present
questions.correct_answer: Temperatures around 21°C with 80% humidity

questions.question_text: What component generates the high voltage required for the spark plugs in the ignition system?
questions.correct_answer: Magneto

questions.question_text: During a magneto check, what is the typical maximum allowable RPM drop for a single magneto?
questions.correct_answer: 125 RPM

questions.question_text: During a magneto check, what is the typical maximum allowable difference in RPM drop between the left and right magnetos?
questions.correct_answer: 50 RPM

questions.question_text: Which structural component forms the central body of the airplane, housing the crew and passengers?
questions.correct_answer: Fuselage

questions.question_text: What is the term for the tail assembly of an aircraft, typically consisting of the vertical and horizontal stabilizers?
questions.correct_answer: Empennage

questions.question_text: Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the ailerons?
questions.correct_answer: Roll

questions.question_text: Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the rudder?
questions.correct_answer: Yaw

questions.question_text: Which basic flight maneuver is primarily controlled by the elevator/stabilator?
questions.correct_answer: Pitch

questions.question_text: According to PCAR Part 5, what is 'Continuing Airworthiness'?
options: The initial certification process for a new aircraft
The set of processes ensuring an aircraft remains compliant and safe throughout its operating life
A special flight permit for non-airworthy aircraft
The process of modifying an aircraft design
questions.correct_answer: The set of processes ensuring an aircraft remains compliant and safe throughout its operating life

questions.question_text: What is Ground Speed (GS)?
options: Indicated airspeed corrected for instrument error
Calibrated airspeed corrected for altitude and temperature
The aircraft's actual speed over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft's actual speed over the ground (TAS adjusted for wind)

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the Fuel Selector Valve in an aircraft?
options: To regulate fuel pressure to the engine
To filter contaminants from the fuel
To select which fuel tank to draw fuel from
To return excess fuel to the tanks
questions.correct_answer: To select which fuel tank to draw fuel from

questions.question_text: What is the function of a tank vent in an aircraft fuel system?
options: To prevent fuel from spilling during maneuvers
To allow the fuel tank to breathe as fuel is consumed or temperature changes
To provide a means for refuelling
questions.correct_answer: To allow the fuel tank to breathe as fuel is consumed or temperature changes

questions.question_text: Which type of oil system requires a separate oil tank and pumps?
questions.correct_answer: Dry Sump System

questions.question_text: What type of oil is recommended for engine maintenance after the initial 50-hour break-in period?
questions.correct_answer: Ashless Dispersant Oil

questions.question_text: What does the oil pressure gauge measure?
options: The quantity of oil in the sump
The quantity of oil flow in PSI (Pounds per Square Inch)
questions.correct_answer: The quantity of oil flow in PSI (Pounds per Square Inch)

questions.question_text: What information does the Oil Temperature Gauge provide?
options: The overall health of the lubrication system
questions.correct_answer: Direct indication of oil temperature

questions.question_text: If oil pressure rises higher than normal levels, what might this indicate?
options: The engine is running too cold
The oil quantity is too low
There is a blockage in the oil system
questions.correct_answer: There is a blockage in the oil system

questions.question_text: If oil temperature falls down to 0, what might this indicate?
options: The oil level is too high
The engine is ready for shutdown
questions.correct_answer: The oil system is compromised

questions.question_text: Operating an engine at higher than its designed temperature can lead to which of the following issues?
options: Increased power output and reduced fuel consumption
Smoother engine operation and extended engine life
questions.correct_answer: Excessive oil consumption and detonation

questions.question_text: Besides the burning fuel, what other factor contributes to high engine temperatures?
options: The friction of moving parts within the engine
questions.correct_answer: The friction of moving parts within the engine

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of air baffles in the engine cowling?
options: To direct cooling air around the engine cylinders
To support the engine within the cowling
questions.correct_answer: To direct cooling air around the engine cylinders

questions.question_text: What does the Cylinder Head Temperature (CHT) gauge measure?
options: The temperature of the engine oil
The average temperature of the engine block
The temperature of the hottest cylinder head
The temperature of the exhaust gases
questions.correct_answer: The temperature of the hottest cylinder head

questions.question_text: Why might a direct current (DC) generator be insufficient to power the entire electrical system at low engine RPM?
options: It primarily charges the battery and does not power other systems directly.
It does not produce a sufficient amount of electrical current at low RPM.
It is designed to only operate at high engine speeds.
questions.correct_answer: It does not produce a sufficient amount of electrical current at low RPM.

questions.question_text: How do alternators in aircraft electrical systems typically produce direct current (DC)?
options: They produce Alternating Current (AC) which is then converted to DC.
They use a series of batteries to convert AC to DC.
They only produce AC and cannot provide DC power.
questions.correct_answer: They produce Alternating Current (AC) which is then converted to DC.

questions.question_text: When are landing lights and taxi lights primarily used?
options: Only during daylight hours for visibility
During all phases of flight for anti-collision purposes
Only when encountering instrument meteorological conditions
questions.correct_answer: On landing and takeoff

questions.question_text: Where is the flap motor typically located for electric flaps?
options: In the fuselage near the pilot's controls
On the right side of the wing
In the empennage near the horizontal stabilizer
questions.correct_answer: On the right side of the wing

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of the Ammeter's scale mentioned in the text?
options: It starts from zero and only shows positive values.
It has a center-zero scale, indicating current flow into or out of the battery.
It shows total electrical load on the alternator.
questions.correct_answer: It has a center-zero scale, indicating current flow into or out of the battery.

questions.question_text: When all other electrical components are turned off, what does a Loadmeter reflect?
options: The total electrical load of the aircraft
The amount of charge remaining in the battery
Only the amount of charging current demanded by the battery
The voltage output of the alternator
questions.correct_answer: Only the amount of charging current demanded by the battery

questions.question_text: In a vacuum-powered gyroscopic instrument system, what does the vacuum gauge indicate?
options: The atmospheric pressure outside the aircraft
The pressure differential across the pitot tube
The vacuum pressure being supplied to the gyros
The oil pressure in the engine
questions.correct_answer: The vacuum pressure being supplied to the gyros

questions.question_text: What are pressure instruments, as described in the text?
options: Instruments that measure mechanical forces within the aircraft structure.
Devices that convert electrical signals into instrument indications.
Pressure sensitive devices that convert pressure from the pitot-static system to cockpit indications.
Instruments that measure changes in temperature.
questions.correct_answer: Pressure sensitive devices that convert pressure from the pitot-static system to cockpit indications.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the drain hole located at the back of the pitot tube chamber?
options: To allow air to enter the pitot tube when stationary.
To equalize pressure with the static port.
To allow moisture to drain from the system in precipitation.
To provide a means for pitot system testing.
questions.correct_answer: To allow moisture to drain from the system in precipitation.

questions.question_text: How is the static port typically vented to capture static pressure?
options: Through a large opening at the front of the aircraft.
Through small holes to the free undisturbed air on the side(s) of the aircraft.
It is connected directly to the pitot tube.
It uses a fan to draw in air from the surrounding environment.
questions.correct_answer: Through small holes to the free undisturbed air on the side(s) of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: How does the static system allow for altimeter and VSI readings to change with atmospheric pressure?
options: It actively pumps air in and out of the instruments.
The pressure moves freely in and out of the instruments through small connecting lines.
It measures temperature changes to infer pressure.
It uses a mechanical linkage directly connected to the outside air.
questions.correct_answer: The pressure moves freely in and out of the instruments through small connecting lines.

questions.question_text: According to the principles of operation, what pushes against a diaphragm inside the airspeed indicator to translate into needle movement?
questions.correct_answer: Ram air (impact pressure)

questions.question_text: What is Calibrated Airspeed (CAS)?
options: Indicated Airspeed (IAS) corrected for installation and instrument errors.
The speed at which the aircraft stalls.
questions.correct_answer: Indicated Airspeed (IAS) corrected for installation and instrument errors.

questions.question_text: As a rule of thumb, how much should be added to Calibrated Airspeed (CAS) for each 1,000 feet of altitude to estimate True Airspeed (TAS)?
questions.correct_answer: 2 percent

questions.question_text: How is Ground Speed (GS) affected by headwinds and tailwinds?
options: It increases with a headwind and decreases with a tailwind.
It decreases with both headwinds and tailwinds.
It decreases with a headwind and increases with a tailwind.
questions.correct_answer: It decreases with a headwind and increases with a tailwind.

questions.question_text: What is Encoded Airspeed?
options: Airspeed transmitted to air traffic control and seen on radar.
Airspeed used for calculating fuel burn.
The speed indicated by the altimeter.
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed transmitted to air traffic control and seen on radar.

questions.question_text: What does VFE, the upper limit of the white arc on the airspeed indicator, represent?
options: The stalling speed in a clean configuration.
The maximum speed with the flaps extended.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum speed with the flaps extended.

questions.question_text: What does VS1, the lower limit of the green arc, represent?
options: The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in a specified clean configuration.
The best rate of climb speed.
questions.correct_answer: The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in a specified clean configuration.

questions.question_text: What does VNO, the upper limit of the green arc, represent?
options: The maximum structural cruising speed, not to be exceeded except in smooth air.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum structural cruising speed, not to be exceeded except in smooth air.

questions.question_text: What is Design Maneuvering Speed (VA)?
options: The minimum speed for safe flight.
The maximum speed at which full control deflection or gusts will not cause structural damage.
The speed at which the aircraft achieves its best glide ratio.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum speed at which full control deflection or gusts will not cause structural damage.

questions.question_text: In what units does the altimeter display altitude?
questions.correct_answer: Feet

questions.question_text: What are the two primary means by which altimeter pointers can be moved?
options: A change in air pressure and adjustment to the barometric scale.
questions.correct_answer: A change in air pressure and adjustment to the barometric scale.

questions.question_text: What is True Altitude?
options: Actual height above Mean Sea Level (MSL).
The altitude shown directly on the altimeter.
questions.correct_answer: Actual height above Mean Sea Level (MSL).

questions.question_text: What is Absolute Altitude?
options: Altitude above International Standard Atmospheric pressure.
Actual height above Mean Sea Level (MSL).
questions.correct_answer: Actual height above Ground Level (AGL).

questions.question_text: What does QNH refer to in altimeter settings?
options: Local station pressure obtained from ATIS or ATC.
Field elevation setting (zero feet on altimeter).
questions.correct_answer: Local station pressure obtained from ATIS or ATC.

questions.question_text: What does QNE refer to in altimeter settings?
options: Field elevation setting (zero feet on altimeter).
questions.correct_answer: Standard pressure setting (29.92 in Hg).

questions.question_text: The Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) contains a diaphragm and what other mechanism to display vertical speed?
options: Connecting linkage and gearing to the indicator pointer.
questions.correct_answer: Connecting linkage and gearing to the indicator pointer.

questions.question_text: How long does it typically take for the VSI to show a stabilized 'Rate' of change?
questions.correct_answer: 6-9 seconds

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of an Alternate Static Port?
options: To provide backup static pressure in case the primary static port is blocked.
To provide pressure for the vacuum system.
questions.correct_answer: To provide backup static pressure in case the primary static port is blocked.

questions.question_text: The Heading Indicator displays the heading on a 360-degree azimuth with what characteristic?
options: It automatically corrects for magnetic variation.
questions.correct_answer: It omits the final zero.

questions.question_text: How often should the Heading Indicator be checked and realigned with the magnetic compass during maneuvers?
questions.correct_answer: Every 3 minutes

questions.question_text: At a standard rate of turn (3° per second), how long does it take to complete a 360° turn?
questions.correct_answer: 2 minutes

questions.question_text: What are 'Isogonic lines' on a navigational chart?
options: Lines connecting points of equal elevation.
Lines connecting places with the same magnetic variations.
Lines indicating areas of high magnetic deviation.
questions.correct_answer: Lines connecting places with the same magnetic variations.

questions.question_text: What are 'Agonic lines' on a navigational chart?
options: Lines joining places with zero magnetic variation.
Lines connecting points of equal magnetic deviation.
questions.correct_answer: Lines joining places with zero magnetic variation.

questions.question_text: What is 'Magnetic Dip'?
options: The angular difference between true and magnetic north.
The error caused by aircraft electrical systems.
The tendency of the magnetic compass card to dip downward towards the Earth's magnetic poles.
The oscillation of the compass during turbulence.
questions.correct_answer: The tendency of the magnetic compass card to dip downward towards the Earth's magnetic poles.

questions.question_text: In the Southern Hemisphere, when accelerating on an East or West heading, the magnetic compass tends to indicate a turn towards:
questions.correct_answer: South

questions.question_text: In the Southern Hemisphere, when initiating a turn from a Northerly heading, the magnetic compass indication will initially:
questions.correct_answer: Lead the actual heading (Overshoot)

questions.question_text: What document, according to the text, presents regulatory requirements for the airworthiness of aircraft operating in the Republic of the Philippines?
questions.correct_answer: PCAR Part 5

questions.question_text: What defines the 'State of Design' according to PCAR Part 5?
options: The state where the aircraft is registered.
The state where the aircraft was manufactured.
The contracting state which approved the original type certificate for an aircraft.
The state where the aircraft is primarily operated.
questions.correct_answer: The contracting state which approved the original type certificate for an aircraft.

questions.question_text: What defines the 'State of Manufacture' according to PCAR Part 5?
options: The state where the aircraft was first designed.
The state where the aircraft is currently registered.
The contracting state under whose authority an aircraft was assembled and approved for operation.
The state that issues the airworthiness certificate.
questions.correct_answer: The contracting state under whose authority an aircraft was assembled and approved for operation.

questions.question_text: What defines the 'State of Registry' according to PCAR Part 5?
options: The state where the aircraft was designed.
The state where the aircraft was manufactured.
The contracting state on whose register the aircraft is entered.
The state where the aircraft is operated most frequently.
questions.correct_answer: The contracting state on whose register the aircraft is entered.

questions.question_text: According to PCAR Part 5, an applicant for a production certificate for aircraft manufactured in the Philippines must comply with the type certificate requirements from which authority?
questions.correct_answer: The State of Design

questions.question_text: What must any component installed in a Philippine Registered aircraft have to ensure airworthiness?
options: A record of its purchase price.
An airworthiness approval tag traceable to an approved standard.
questions.correct_answer: An airworthiness approval tag traceable to an approved standard.

questions.question_text: Besides an Attitude Indicator, which other instrument is specifically required for VFR flight at night according to the list?
questions.correct_answer: Stabilized Direction Indicator (DG)

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT part of the minimum instrument requirements for VFR flight during the day?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator

questions.question_text: What is defined as the 'alteration of an aircraft product in conformity with approved standards'?
questions.correct_answer: Modification

questions.question_text: What must an applicant for a Certificate of Airworthiness demonstrate regarding aircraft identification?
options: That the aircraft is painted in a specific color scheme.
That the aircraft has unique decorative markings.
That the aircraft is properly registered and marked, including identification plates.
That the aircraft's serial number is less than 100.
questions.correct_answer: That the aircraft is properly registered and marked, including identification plates.

questions.question_text: As part of continuing airworthiness, what must authorized maintenance personnel do regarding aircraft maintenance records?
options: Obtain pilot approval for all entries.
Make appropriate entries certifying the aircraft is airworthy.
Keep records separate from the aircraft.
Only record major repairs, not minor maintenance.
questions.correct_answer: Make appropriate entries certifying the aircraft is airworthy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT listed as a major aircraft classification in the provided text?
questions.correct_answer: Spacecraft

questions.question_text: What is the definition of a 'Normal' category airplane?
options: Aircraft containing nine or fewer seats and a maximum takeoff weight of 12,500 pounds or less.
Aircraft used for specific agricultural purposes.
questions.correct_answer: Aircraft containing nine or fewer seats and a maximum takeoff weight of 12,500 pounds or less.

questions.question_text: What defines a 'Transport' category airplane?
options: More than 10 seats if jet, more than 19 if piston, and specified MTOWs (12,500lbs Jet/19,000lbs Prop).
questions.correct_answer: More than 10 seats if jet, more than 19 if piston, and specified MTOWs (12,500lbs Jet/19,000lbs Prop).

questions.question_text: What are key characteristics of a 'Commuter' category airplane?
options: Propeller-driven, multi-engine, no more than 19 pax, 19,000 lbs MTOW, 60° bank.
Designed for specific use like forest services.
questions.correct_answer: Propeller-driven, multi-engine, no more than 19 pax, 19,000 lbs MTOW, 60° bank.

questions.question_text: What distinguishes an 'Aerobatic' category aircraft?
questions.correct_answer: No flight maneuver restrictions.

questions.question_text: Aircraft used for research and development, crew training, or exhibition are typically classified under which category?
questions.correct_answer: Experimental

questions.question_text: What type of aircraft category is reserved for military aircraft converted or modified for civilian use?
questions.correct_answer: Limited

questions.question_text: What does the fuselage house besides providing structural connection?
options: The cabin and/or cockpit with seats and controls.
questions.correct_answer: The cabin and/or cockpit with seats and controls.

questions.question_text: What structural connections does the fuselage provide?
options: For the wings and tail assembly.
questions.correct_answer: For the wings and tail assembly.

questions.question_text: Which type of fuselage construction is characterized by an open truss structure, often covered with cloth fabric?
questions.correct_answer: Truss Type

questions.question_text: Which fuselage construction type uses stressed skin to support almost all loads, similar to a beverage can, and is not highly tolerant to surface deformation?
questions.correct_answer: Monocoque

questions.question_text: An airplane design with a single set of wings is known as a:
questions.correct_answer: Monoplane

questions.question_text: An airplane design with two sets of wings is known as a:
questions.correct_answer: Bi-plane

questions.question_text: An airplane design with three sets of wings is known as a:
questions.correct_answer: Triplane

questions.question_text: Which wing planform is described as ideal for slow speeds?
questions.correct_answer: Straight or Regular Wings

questions.question_text: Which wing planform is noted for having less drag than a regular wing, with Cessna using a semi-taper variation?
questions.correct_answer: Moderate Taper Wing

questions.question_text: Which wing planform is ideal for higher speeds?
questions.correct_answer: Sweptback Wing

questions.question_text: Which wing planform is described as ideal for supersonic speeds and is used by fighter jets?
questions.correct_answer: Delta Wing

questions.question_text: What does 'Aspect Ratio' refer to in the context of wings?
options: The angle at which the wing meets the fuselage.
The ratio of the wing's span to its average chord.
The thickness of the wing at its widest point.
The amount of sweepback in the wing.
questions.correct_answer: The ratio of the wing's span to its average chord.

questions.question_text: How do the flaps on an airplane typically move in relation to each other?
options: In opposite directions to control roll.
In the same direction to increase lift and drag simultaneously.
They pivot in the vertical plane.
questions.correct_answer: In the same direction to increase lift and drag simultaneously.

questions.question_text: How do the vertical and horizontal stabilizers of the empennage function collectively?
options: They generate all of the aircraft's lift.
They provide thrust for forward movement.
They steady the airplane and help maintain a straight path through the air.
They house the main landing gear.
questions.correct_answer: They steady the airplane and help maintain a straight path through the air.

questions.question_text: How is the rudder operated by the pilot?
options: By pushing or pulling the control wheel.
With the use of rudder pedals.
Through an automatic yaw damping system.
questions.correct_answer: With the use of rudder pedals.

questions.question_text: What are 'Ground Adjustable Tabs' typically used for?
options: To adjust the trim of the aircraft only while on the ground.
To control the aircraft's speed during taxi.
To provide additional lift during takeoff.
To adjust the angle of attack during flight.
questions.correct_answer: To adjust the trim of the aircraft only while on the ground.

questions.question_text: A 'Ground Adjustable Rudder' implies that the rudder's effectiveness can be altered when?
options: Only during maintenance checks in a hangar.
Only when the aircraft is on the ground and stationary.
Automatically during flight based on wind conditions.
questions.correct_answer: Only when the aircraft is on the ground and stationary.

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of a 'Rudder Trim' system?
options: To directly control the aircraft's yaw movement.
To adjust the rudder position to relieve pedal pressure for the pilot.
To increase the speed of the aircraft during cruise.
To retract the rudder for storage.
questions.correct_answer: To adjust the rudder position to relieve pedal pressure for the pilot.

questions.question_text: How is the elevator operated by the pilot to control pitch movement?
options: By turning the control wheel left or right.
By pulling the control wheel to pitch up or pushing to pitch down.
By pressing a button on the glareshield.
questions.correct_answer: By pulling the control wheel to pitch up or pushing to pitch down.

questions.question_text: The text refers to the Elevator Trim as the 'poor man's autopilot'. What does this imply about its function?
options: It can fully automate the aircraft's flight path.
It provides basic stability and reduces pilot workload in maintaining a desired pitch attitude.
It is a less reliable alternative to the main elevator.
It is only used in emergency situations.
questions.correct_answer: It provides basic stability and reduces pilot workload in maintaining a desired pitch attitude.

questions.question_text: What is a key characteristic of a 'Stabilator' empennage design?
options: It has a separate horizontal stabilizer and elevator.
It is a one-piece horizontal stabilizer that pivots up and down on a central hinge.
It functions primarily to control yaw.
It is only found on jet aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: It is a one-piece horizontal stabilizer that pivots up and down on a central hinge.

questions.question_text: What is the function of an 'Anti-Servo Tab' on a stabilator?
options: To increase the control forces on the stabilator.
To make the stabilator more sensitive to pilot input.
To decrease the control forces on the stabilator and provide better feel.
To provide emergency pitch control if the main stabilator fails.
questions.correct_answer: To decrease the control forces on the stabilator and provide better feel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT listed as a type of landing gear contact surface?
questions.correct_answer: Track (caterpillar)

questions.question_text: What is another name for 'Conventional' landing gear?
questions.correct_answer: Tail Dragger

questions.question_text: What distinguishes 'Fixed' landing gear?
options: It can be retracted into the aircraft structure during flight.
It is designed for water landings only.
It remains extended at all times and cannot be retracted.
It uses a spring steel shock absorption system.
questions.correct_answer: It remains extended at all times and cannot be retracted.

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of 'Retractable' landing gear?
options: It is permanently extended for all operations.
It can be folded or drawn into the aircraft fuselage or wings during flight.
It is only used on tail dragger aircraft.
It is designed solely for short-field takeoffs.
questions.correct_answer: It can be folded or drawn into the aircraft fuselage or wings during flight.

questions.question_text: What specific type of shock absorber is an Oleo Strut?
options: A rigid strut with no shock absorption.
questions.correct_answer: An air-oil shock absorber.

questions.question_text: What type of main landing gear is described as using 'Spring Steel' to absorb and transmit shock to the airframe?
questions.correct_answer: Spring steel landing gear.

questions.question_text: What type of brakes are commonly used on the main wheels of most light general aviation airplanes?
questions.correct_answer: Hydraulically actuated disc brakes.

questions.question_text: What is a 'Fixed-Pitch Propeller'?
options: A propeller whose blade angles can be adjusted automatically in flight.
A propeller whose pitch is set by the manufacturer and cannot be changed.
A propeller that can only be adjusted on the ground with the engine off.
A propeller designed for high-speed cruise only.
questions.correct_answer: A propeller whose pitch is set by the manufacturer and cannot be changed.

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of a 'Cruise Propeller'?
options: Designed for climb, with a bigger bite.
Designed for efficient cruise, with slower climb performance.
Automatically adjusts its pitch in flight.
questions.correct_answer: Designed for efficient cruise, with slower climb performance.

questions.question_text: What defines a 'Ground Adjustable Propeller'?
options: Its blade angle can be adjusted only when the aircraft is on the ground and the engine is not running.
It automatically adjusts its pitch in flight.
It has a fixed pitch that cannot be changed.
It is controlled by the pilot from the cockpit during flight.
questions.correct_answer: Its blade angle can be adjusted only when the aircraft is on the ground and the engine is not running.

questions.question_text: What mechanism automatically varies the pitch of a constant-speed propeller to maintain constant RPM?
questions.correct_answer: A governor.

questions.question_text: In a 'Direct Drive Propeller' system, what is the relationship between the propeller and the engine crankshaft?
options: The propeller is connected to the crankshaft through a gearbox.
The propeller is directly connected to the crankshaft.
The propeller is driven by an electric motor.
The propeller is connected to the camshaft.
questions.correct_answer: The propeller is directly connected to the crankshaft.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a 'Spinner' on an aircraft?
options: To house the propeller pitch change mechanism.
A streamlined fairing fitted over a propeller hub or at the center of a turbofan engine.
questions.correct_answer: A streamlined fairing fitted over a propeller hub or at the center of a turbofan engine.

questions.question_text: What is a disadvantage of a Radial Engine, besides its large frontal area?
options: Higher temperature due to cylinder formation.
questions.correct_answer: Prone to fluid lock.

questions.question_text: What are the advantages of an In-line engine, according to the text?
options: Better cooling due to cylinder design.
Minimal drag due to low frontal area.
questions.correct_answer: Minimal drag due to low frontal area.

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic disadvantage of most V-Type engines?
options: They are water cooled and have expensive maintenance.
Large frontal area resulting in high drag.
questions.correct_answer: They are water cooled and have expensive maintenance.

questions.question_text: Which engine component houses the piston and provides the combustion chamber?
questions.correct_answer: Cylinder

questions.question_text: What is the 'Piston' within a reciprocating engine?
options: A stationary part that directs air flow.
A movable bar inside the cylinder.
questions.correct_answer: A movable bar inside the cylinder.

questions.question_text: What is the function of the 'Crankshaft' in a piston engine?
options: To open and close the valves.
To transmit the rotating force to the propeller.
questions.correct_answer: To transmit the rotating force to the propeller.

questions.question_text: What are the 'Intake and Exhaust Valves' in a piston engine?
options: Parts where the fuel and air mixture enters and exhaust gases exit.
Components that filter contaminants from the fuel.
questions.correct_answer: Parts where the fuel and air mixture enters and exhaust gases exit.

questions.question_text: Which engine component is responsible for opening and closing the intake and exhaust valves?
questions.correct_answer: Camshaft

questions.question_text: What is the 'Crankcase' in a piston engine?
options: The component that houses the carburetor.
The housing for the crankshaft and other internal components.
The part that connects the engine to the propeller.
questions.correct_answer: The housing for the crankshaft and other internal components.

questions.question_text: During the 'Intake' stroke of a four-stroke cycle engine, what happens?
options: The piston moves upward, expelling exhaust gases.
The piston moves downward, drawing fuel/air mixture into the cylinder.
The spark plug ignites the mixture.
The piston moves upward, compressing the mixture.
questions.correct_answer: The piston moves downward, drawing fuel/air mixture into the cylinder.

questions.question_text: During the 'Power' stroke of a four-stroke cycle engine, what happens?
options: Fuel and air are drawn into the cylinder.
The ignited mixture expands, pushing the piston downward and rotating the crankshaft.
Exhaust gases are expelled from the cylinder.
questions.correct_answer: The ignited mixture expands, pushing the piston downward and rotating the crankshaft.

questions.question_text: During the 'Exhaust' stroke of a four-stroke cycle engine, what happens?
options: The piston moves downward, drawing in air.
The exhaust valve opens, and the piston moves upward to expel gases.
questions.correct_answer: The exhaust valve opens, and the piston moves upward to expel gases.

questions.question_text: What characterizes 'Normal Combustion' in an engine?
options: Explosive ignition of the fuel/air mixture.
A smooth buildup of temperature and pressure, maximizing force to the piston.
Incomplete burning of fuel, leading to power loss.
questions.correct_answer: A smooth buildup of temperature and pressure, maximizing force to the piston.

questions.question_text: What is 'Abnormal Combustion' in an engine cylinder?
options: The expected, efficient burning of fuel and air.
An uncontrolled or premature burning of the fuel and air mixture.
Combustion that only occurs at high altitudes.
questions.correct_answer: An uncontrolled or premature burning of the fuel and air mixture.

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of the Outside Air Temperature (OAT) Gauge?
options: To provide the temperature of the air outside the aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: To provide the temperature of the air outside the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is the ideal air-to-fuel mixture ratio mentioned for engine operation?
